contextId.information: Here "name" means to "say." AT: "Each man had to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "fell dead" means to suddenly die.   AT: "suddenly died before Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here the word "spirit" refers to a person's attitude and emotions. The idea of the spirit "coming on him" means that he began to have these jealous feelings. AT: "a man might feel jealous for no reason" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: a spirit of jealousy might falsely come on a man

contextId.information: The words "gone astray" is an idiom that means "to be unfaithful." AT: "if you have not been unfaithful to your husband" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: if you have not gone astray

contextId.information: The phrase to "be free" from something means to not be harmed by it. AT: "this bitter water will not harm you, though it is able to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: you will be free from this bitter water

contextId.information: The words "strays away" is an idiom that means "to be unfaithful."  AT: "who is unfaithful to her husband" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: who strays away from her husband

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means that he suspects that his wife has been unfaithful to him by sleeping with another man. AT: "and suspects that his wife has been unfaithful to him" or "and suspects that his wife has slept with another man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: when he is jealous of his wife

contextId.information: "To separate yourself to someone" means to "dedicate yourself" to that person. AT: "dedicates himself ... he dedicates himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. Here "separation" means "dedication" AT: "vow of dedication" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "separation" means "dedication." AT: "dedicates ... dedicated ... dedication" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "separation" means "dedication." Also, this abstract noun can be expressed as a verb. AT: "of his dedication" or "that he has dedicated himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] or [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

Here "separation" means "dedication." Also, this abstract noun may be written as a verb. AT: "indicating his dedication" or "indicating how he has separated himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

Here "separation" means "dedication." Also, this abstract noun can be expressed with the verb "separated." AT: "indicating dedication" or "indicating that he has dedicated himself to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

- Here "separation" means "dedication." Also, this abstract noun may be written as a verb. AT: "his dedication" or "for having dedicated himself to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is an idiom. Here "keep" means to "protect." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom which means to have kind intentions towards someone. It can also be expressed by smiling. AT: "smile at you" (UDB) or "look at you with kindness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: make his face shine on you

contextId.information: The phrase "set apart" means to be dedicated to a specific purpose. In this case, the offerings were dedicated to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. "To open the womb" means to give birth for the first time. Here this refers to the first male child to which a mother gives birth. AT: "child who is the firstborn son of his mother" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: male child who opens the womb

contextId.information: Here "they" refers to the people of Israel. The phrase "came out" means to leave. AT: "after they left the land of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: after they came out from the land of Egypt

contextId.information: Here the word "keep" means to observe. AT: "observe the Festival of the Passover" or "celebrate the Festival of the Passover" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: keep the Festival of the Passover

contextId.information: Here the word "keep" means to observe. AT: "observe the Passover" or "celebrate the Passover" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "keep" means to observe. AT: "observe the Passover" or "celebrate the Passover" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "keep" means to observe. AT: "observe the Passover" or "celebrate the Passover" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This phrase "call to mind" means to remember. AT: "remember you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "watch out" means to guide and to take care of. AT: "You can guide us and show us how to live in the desert" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: You must watch out for us

contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "This responsibility is too difficult for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: They are too much for me

contextId.information: This represents doing more than one should. AT: "You have done more than you should" or "You assume to have more authority than you should" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "in Yahweh's presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This represents doing more than one should. AT: "You have done more than you should" or "You assume to have more authority than you should" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "raised up to me" represents giving or offering something to God. This can be stated in active form. AT: "the offerings that people give to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: the offerings raised up to me

contextId.information: This idiom means that they would simply travel through the area by walking. They would not come in chariots to attack the people of Edom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. It is a way of saying that the mountain is high, and speaks of the mountain as if it were a person who looks down to see the wilderness below him. AT: "rises above the wilderness" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

The increase in God's anger is spoken of as if it was a fire starting to burn. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God became very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The increase in Balaam's anger is spoken of as if it was a fire starting to burn. This can be stated in active form. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:21|22:22]]. AT: "Balaam became very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "raised his eyes" is an idiom that means to look up. AT: "He looked up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means he sees and understands clearly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "eyes open" is an idiom that means Balaam has received the ability to know what God wants to say. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means he sees and understands clearly. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:24:02|24:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means a person who will lead all the people and also lead the army into battle. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: a man who may go out and come in before them and lead them out and bring them in

contextId.information: This is an idiom. Here the word "keep" means to observe or celebrate. The word "him" refers to Yahweh. AT: "you must observe the festival for Yahweh" or "you must celebrate the festival for Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: you must keep the festival for him

contextId.information: This is an idiom. It means that her vows will remain in effect and that she will be required to fulfill them. AT: "she will be obligated to fulfill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. It means that her vows will not remain in effect and she will be not required to fulfill them. AT: "she will not be obligated to fulfill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. Being "under" her vows means that she is committed to them and that they are still in effect. AT: "while she is still committed to those vows" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: while she is under those vows

contextId.information: This is an idiom. The phrase "remain in force" means that her vows will remain in effect and she will be required to fulfill them. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:num:30:03|30:4]]. AT: "then she must fulfill all her vows ... she must fulfill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: then all her vows must stand ... remain in force

contextId.information: This is an idiom. It means that her vows will not remain in effect and she will be not required to fulfill them. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:num:30:06|30:6]]. AT: "she will not be obligated to fulfill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This can be stated in active form. AT: "the relative must certainly execute the accused man" or "the accused man must die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the accused who struck him must surely be put to death
